importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the previous government shutdown that lasted 35 days, making it the longest in nearly 50 years.
The end date of the previous government shutdown, marking the conclusion of the longest government shutdown in history.
The current date of the article's update, indicating that the government shutdown is ongoing as of this time.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The duration of the 2018–2019 shutdown, which was the longest in U.S. history, lasting 35 days.
The current government shutdown, which has not yet been resolved due to lack of passage of 12 appropriations bills.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown lasted 35 days, from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019, and is considered the longest in nearly 50 years.
The 2018–2019 shutdown cost the U.S. economy an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP according to the Congressional Budget Office (CBO).
The 2018 shutdown was partial, with 800,000 federal employees affected — approximately 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted from pay but required to report to work.
The current shutdown is a full government shutdown, meaning no appropriations bills have been passed by Congress to fund the U.S. government.
Since 1981, there have been six government shutdowns since 1990, indicating a growing trend of political gridlock in Congress.

Republican Speaker Mike Johnson leads a House majority that is one of the narrowest in history, and the GOP lacks 60 votes in the Senate to overcome a filibuster, complicating bipartisan negotiations.
The U.S. government first implemented shutdown procedures in the early 1980s when agencies were instructed to cease operations during funding lapses.

namedEntities.name: United States federal government
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The national government of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The entity that is currently shut down, highlighting a critical breakdown in funding and political compromise.

namedEntities.name: Congress
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The legislative body of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Congress failed to pass necessary appropriations bills, leading directly to the ongoing shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Capitol Hill
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The location of the U.S. Congress and legislative activities
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The site where negotiations and legislative action are taking place, where funding deals remain out of reach.

namedEntities.name: Republican Speaker Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The current Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His narrow majority and lack of Senate support make legislative compromise difficult, contributing to the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The nonpartisan office that provides economic analysis
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The CBO estimated that the 2018 shutdown cost the U.S. $3 billion in lost GDP.

namedEntities.name: 12 appropriations bills
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Legislative bills needed to fund federal agencies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: No passage of these bills has occurred, resulting in a full government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Furloughed employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal workers who were not paid and not required to work
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Approximately 300,000 were furloughed during the 2018 shutdown, impacting public services.

namedEntities.name: Exempted employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal workers required to report to work but not paid
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These employees were not furloughed but unpaid during the 2018 shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Senate filibuster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A procedural rule allowing extended debate to block legislation
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The GOP lacks the 60 votes needed to override a filibuster, blocking passage of spending bills.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of the article providing updates and analysis on the ongoing government shutdown.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. federal government is currently experiencing a full shutdown due to Congress failing to pass the 12 required appropriations bills. This follows the 2018–2019 shutdown, which lasted 35 days — the longest in nearly 50 years — and cost an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP. The previous shutdown was partial, with 800,000 federal employees affected, including 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted from pay. The current shutdown reflects deep political gridlock, exacerbated by a narrow Republican majority in the House and a lack of Senate votes to overcome a filibuster. With no funding agreement in sight, federal services are being disrupted, highlighting systemic challenges in U.S. legislative cooperation.
title: The last government shutdown was the longest in nearly 50 years. Here are all the recent shutdowns in one chart
